summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ/OIG Special Agents with a BOP Unit Manager regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on the events of August 9, 2019, including a phone call Epstein made that evening, the failure to provide him with a cellmate after his previous cellmate was transferred, and the manager's observations and speculations about the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the investigation. The interview discusses his request for a phone call, his lack of an activated phone account, and the circumstances leading to his death.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Former cellmate of Jeffrey Epstein. The witness mentions an alleged assault incident between Tartaglione and Epstein that led to an SIS investigation and Tartaglione being moved.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate who was transferred (WAB - With All Belongings) on the morning of August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

persons.name: R. Kelly
persons.context: Mentioned as an example of another high-profile inmate at MCC who had his phone account properly set up, unlike Epstein.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: Referenced in the context of the response to Epstein's hanging. The witness speculates about the difficulty of a single officer cutting down a hanging inmate.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: SHU officer present during Epstein's phone call on August 9, 2019. The witness instructed Noel and others to end the call after 15 minutes.

events.title: Epstein requests and receives phone PIN
events.description: Epstein encountered the unit manager while being escorted to meet with lawyers. He requested help setting up his phone PIN and pack because his normal unit manager was on leave. The manager provided him with the paper printout on either Wednesday, August 7th, or Thursday, August 8th.

events.title: Epstein's final phone call
events.description: At approximately 6:45 PM, Epstein was given a 15-minute phone call on a legal line in the G-tier shower area. He said he wanted to call his mother, but a male answered. The call was not monitored or logged. The unit manager left at 7:00 PM after instructing officers to end the call after 15 minutes.

events.title: Epstein found deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The witness was called to the hospital where Epstein's body had been transported and later took pictures of the body.

events.title: Witness writes memo on events
events.description: The unit manager wrote a memorandum for file detailing the phone call given to Epstein on August 9, 2019.

events.title: OIG Interview
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with the BOP unit manager regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), Brooklyn, New York (interview location)
Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York (primary location of events)
G-tier shower, SHU, MCC (where Epstein's final phone call was made)
keyFacts: Epstein was given a 15-minute phone call on a legal line on the evening of August 9, 2019, shortly before he was found deceased. The call was not monitored or logged, which the witness admits was a failure.

Epstein's cellmate, Reyes, was transferred (WAB) out of MCC on the morning of August 9, 2019. Epstein was left without a cellmate, contrary to requirements. The witness states the responsibility for ensuring a replacement cellmate fell on the SHU lieutenant or captain.

The witness states it was common practice at MCC for staff to give inmates unauthorized phone calls on legal lines, and that proper monitoring/logging procedures and equipment (like a logbook) were not in place at the time.

The witness took pictures of Epstein's deceased body at the hospital with his personal phone and sent them to an Associate Warden, then deleted them. He did this to document the time of departure and provide proof of death.

The witness speculates that the official response to Epstein's hanging may have been improper, suggesting it's unlikely a single officer could have cut down a hanging inmate of Epstein's size without proper tools and assistance, and that entering a cell alone in such a situation is against policy.
